MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING 
 
 
This Memorandum of Understanding (hereinafter referred to as “M O U  ” ) is entered on 
this 16 /05/2024 and is made effective from (“  Effective Date ” ) 01/06/2024 and 30/06/2025 
 
Swasti, a registered Society under Karnataka Societies Registration Act, 1960 
having its registered office at No. 25, AECS Layout, 1st Main, AECS Layout, Ashwath 
Nagar Bangalore 560094, Karnataka (hereinafter referred as “Organization” , 
which expression shall, unless repugnant to or inconsistent with the context or 
meaning thereof, be deemed to include its successors and permitted assigns) 
AND 
Pragati Koraput, incorporated/registered under the Societies Registration Act 1960 
having its registered office at Pujariput Post & Koraput District Pin 
code:764020, Odisha, India (hereinafter referred as “ Partner ” , which expression 
shall, unless repugnant to or inconsistent with the context or meaning thereof, be 
deemed to include its successors and permitted assigns) 
 
Organization and Partner shall be collectively referred to as “ Parties ” and 
individually as “ Party ” . 
WHEREAS: 
1. The Organization is engaged in the business of SWASTI is a Global South civil 
society Organisation that is committed to adding 100 million ‘wealthy days’ 
for Vulnerable Communities.  SWASTI upgrades the discourse from  health to  
wellbeing and brings the missing pieces in wellbeing together (social, 
behavioral, management and technology) around the technical/medical 
aspects, with a strong focus on Prevention and Promotion- and therein lies its 
uniqueness. SWASTI strives to partner with communities in making  
everyday well -being real for the most vulnerable. SWASTI is part of the Catalyst 
Group of  institutions, working across 25 countries in South Asia, Southeast 
Asia, and parts of East Africa. 
 
2. The Partner is engaged in the business of Pragati is working for the socio - 
economic well -being of forest -dependent communities, small and marginal 
farmers, women -headed and migrant households in the most fragile landscape 
of Odisha, India. Their efforts re volve around principles of conservation, 
utilization, and management of natural resources, reviving and 
rebuilding sustainable agriculture practices in order to achieve the vision of a 
society free from hunger with agro ecological restoration. Pragati is 
responding to the issues of climate change and humanitarian crises by 
building the capacities of communities and ecosystems. Empowerment of 
women and working through farmers’ collectives are the key strategies 
adopted for sustainability and community ownership.  The present 
operational areas of Pragati span over 14 blocks of Koraput District of South  
Odisha reaching out to the bottom of the pyramid population. Our 
collaboration with Government, Research Institutions, National and 
International Donors, and Civil Society Networks has strengthened our efforts 
for the realization of larger societal goals. 
 
 
IT HAS BEEN AGREED BETWEEN THE PARTIES AS FOLLOWS : 
 
1. EFFECTIVE DATE AND TERM. 
 
1.1. This MOU is deemed to have come into force as on 01/06/2024 and shall be valid 
for a period of one year from the Effective Date. 
 
2. CONSIDERATION AND PAYMENT TERMS 
 
2.1. There will be no financial transactions between the parties. Each party is  
responsible for the expenses incurred while carrying out their respective  
activities as outlined below. 
 
3. UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE PARTNERS. 
 
3.1. The Organization is desirous of entering into this MOU for supporting the  
partner for Call4Svasth, social protection, Investment for Wellness (i4We) and 
other Organization program. These are initiatives of Organisation  aimed at 
providing holistic healthcare and building resilience within the community 
through technology levers. 
3.2. Funding opportunities are explored by both parties. 
 
4. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY. 
 
4.1. All pre-existing intellectual property rights shall continue to vest with the  
owner of such intellectual property rights. 
4.2. The Parties recognize that all third party Intellectual Property Rights are the 
exclusive property of their respective owners. 
5. CONFIDENTIALITY 
 
5.1. Confidentiality obligations specified above will not apply to the following  
cases: 
a. Such Confidential Information has been placed in the public domain  
other than through the fault of the Receiving Party; 
b. The Confidential Information has already been in the possession of the 
Receiving Party before the Disclosing party provided it to the Receiving  
Party; 
c. The Confidential Information has been received by the Receiving Party  
from a third party; 
d. The Confidential Information was developed independently by the  
Receiving Party without any inputs from the Disclosing Party; 
e. The Receiving Party is required to disclose the Confidential Information 
by law. 
 
6. INDEMNIFICATION 
 
6.1. Neither Party shall be liable to the other Party for any indirect, incidental,  
contingent, consequential, ancillary, punitive, exemplary, special or similar  
damages, including but not limited to, loss of profits or loss of data, whether 
incurred as a  resul t of negligence or otherwise, irrespective of whether either  
Party has been advised of the possibility of the incurrence by the other Party 
of any such damages. 
 
7. TERMINATION 
 
7.1. Either Party shall have the right to terminate this MOU by giving written 
notice of  30 days to the  other in the event that: (a) the other  Party has 
committed a material breach of any of its obligations hereunder which cannot 
be remedied; (b) the other Party has committed a material or repeated breach of 
any of its obligations hereunder and h as failed to remedy such breach (if the 
same is capable of remedy) within 15 (Fifteen) days of being required by  
written notice so to do;  (c) the other Party goes into l  liquidation (whether 
compulsory or voluntary) or an administrator or receiver is appointed over 
the whole or any part of that other Party’s assets or if that other Party enters  
into any  arrangement for the benefit  of or compounds with  its creditors  
generally or threatens to do any  of these things or  any judgment is made 
against that other Party or any similar occurrence under any jurisdiction 
affects that other Party; or (d) the other Party ceases or threatens to cease to carry 
on business or is removed  from the relevant register  of companies, where 
applicable; or (e) there is a change in control of the other Party; or (f) 
the other Party takes or suffers any similar or analogous action in any 
jurisdiction in consequence of debt. 
 
7.2. Either Party’s right to terminate this MOU shall be without prejudice to the  
other rights and remedies it may have under Applicable Law. 
 
7.3. In the event the Organization terminates this MOU pursuant to Clause 7.1  
above, the Organization shall have no further liability to the Partner, except  
to pay all sums that are already due and payable to the Partner the date of  
termination. 
 
7.4. Nothing in this MOU shall prevent the Parties from terminating the MOU for 
convenience by providing a written notice of 30 days to the other Party. 
 
8. CONSEQUENCES OF TERMINATION 
 
8.1. Upon expiry or termination of this MOU: 
(a) the rights of both Parties under this MOU shall terminate; 
(b) the Parties shall immediately cease to use all of the other Party’s 
Intellectual Property Rights, including but not limited to trademarks,  
copyrights and all material, including marketing materials and the  
other Parties' logos; 
(c) Parties shall perform the Services through the notice period, unless  
otherwise indicated by the other Party and shall assist and cooperate  
fully with the other Party to perform any transitional services as may  
be required by the other Party; and 
(d) the Parties shall promptly return the Confidential information of the  
other Party or certify in writing to the other Party that he/she/it has  
destroyed all Confidential Information. 
 
9. NON - SOLICITATION 
 
9.1. The Parties shall not, during the term of this MOU and for a period of 12  
(Twelve) months thereafter, solicit any personnel employed/engaged by the 
other Party or solicit or attempt to solicit any existing clients or customers of 
the other Party. 
 
10. REVIEW PROCESS 
 
The Parties to this MOU will  hold a status review meeting once every 3(Three)  
months to review the status and progress of the Service. 
11. AMENDMENT 
 
Any amendment, modification, change or revision to this MOU shall be  
subject to mutual agreement by both the Parties 
 
12. ASSIGNMENT 
 
This MOU and the rights and obligations herein may not be assigned by any 
Party without the written consent of the other Party, which consent may not  
be unreasonably withheld. 
 
13. RELATIONSHIP 
 
The Parties shall work on a principle-to-principle basis and as independent 
contractors. This MOU does not create a partnership, franchise, joint venture,  
agency, fiduciary or employment relationship between the Parties. 
 
14. GOVERNING LAW AND JURISDICTION 
 
14.1. This MOU shall be construed and enforced in accordance with the laws of India 
without regard to its principles of conflict of laws provisions. Subject to Clause 
16 below, the Courts in Bangalore shall have the exclusive jurisdiction to 
entertain any dispute es arising out of, under, or in relation to, the provisions of 
this MOU, including any proceedings for interim relief arising out of  actions 
taken by any Party, whether under the provisions of this MOU or on  account 
of a breach of this MOU, and whether during pendency of any mediation and/or 
arbitration proceedings, or thereafter. 
 
15. DISPUTE RESOLUTION 
 
15.1. Any and all disputes arising out of or in connection with this MOU shall be  
referred by written notice, and the Parties shall meet and endeavor to resolve 
the dispute within 30 days. Parties can by mutual agreement extend the period 
of resolution in the above process. 
 
15.2. In the event the Parties are unable to resolve the dispute in accordance with  
Clause 16.1 above, the Parties shall submit such dispute to mediation at the  
Centre for Advanced Mediation Practice (“ CAMP ” ), Bangalore under the CAMP 
Rules of Mediation, 2015 as may be modified or revised from time to time. 
15.3. If the dispute between the Parties is not resolved through mediation, the 
same shall be resolved by arbitration in accordance with the Arbitration and 
Conciliation Act, 1996. The Dispute shall be settled by a sole arbitrator to be 
appointed by the Parties to the dispute. If the Parties are unable to appoint a 
sole arbitrator by way of mutual consent, then such arbitrator shall be 
appointed pursuant to the provisions of Section 11 of the Arbitration and 
Conciliation Act, 1996. The seat of arbitration shall b e Bangalore, India and 
the arbitration proceedings shall be governed by the provisions of the 
Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, as amended  from time to time. All  
arbitration proceedings shall be conducted in English. The arbitration award  
shall be final and binding on the Parties and shall be enforceable in any 
competent court of law, and the Parties agree to be bound thereby and to act 
accordingly. 
 
15.4. Notwithstanding anything stated to the contrary in this MOU, neither of the  
Parties shall be precluded from seeking interim or permanent equitable or  
injunctive relief, or both, from any court having jurisdiction to grant the same. 
The pursuit of equitable  or injunctive relief shall not be a waiver of the  duty of 
the Parties to pursue any remedy for monetary damages through the mediation 
and/or arbitration as specified above. 
 
16. FORCE MAJEURE 
 
16.1. Neither Party shall be considered in  default in the performance of his/her/its  
obligation under the MOU, if such performance is prevented or delayed on 
account of war, civil commotion, strike, epidemics, accidents, fires, 
unprecedented floods, earthquake o r because of promulgation of any law or 
regulations by  the Government, unforeseen breakdowns or  account of any  
other acts of god. At the time of occurrence of a Force Majeure condition, the 
affected Party shall give a notice in writing within fifteen (15) days from the 
date of occurrence of the Force Majeure condition indicating the cause of 
Force Majeure condition and the period for which the Force Majeure condition 
was likely to subsist. In the event the affected Party is prevented from 
fulfilling his/her /its obligation under the MOU owing to the Force Majeure 
condition continuing for more than thirty (30) days, both Parties shall consult 
each other regarding the continuation of the MOU and the other Party may decide 
to release the affected Party from performing its obligation hereunder or may 
modify the relevant provisions of this MOU affected by the Force Majeure event so 
long as the Force Majeure event continues, in order to enable the affected Party 
to perform its other obligations hereunder as so modified. 
 
16.2. For the purpose of this MOU , “ Force Majeure ” means an act of God, war, civil 
disturbance, strike, lockout, act of terrorism, flood, fire, explosion or 
legislation or restriction by any government or other authority, or any other  
similar circumstance beyond the control of any Party, which has the effect of 
wholly or partially suspending the obligations hereunder, of the Party 
concerned during the continuance and to the extent of such prevention, 
interruption or hindrance. 
 
17. NOTICE 
 
17.1. Except as may be otherwise provided herein, notices or other 
communications to be given shall be made in writing and by letter or email  
conversation (followed by written notice by registered post). All notices sent 
by either Parties will be to the address of the other party mentioned above. 
 
18. NON - ASSIGNMENT 
 
The Partner shall not assign or transfer its rights and obligations under this 
MOU without the prior written consent of the Organization. 
 
19. SEVERABILITY 
 
The Parties acknowledge and agree that if any of the provision of this MOU is  
deemed invalid, void, illegal, and unenforceable that provision stands severed  
from this MOU and the remaining provisions of this MOU shall remain valid 
and enforceable. 
 
20. ENTIRE AGREEMENT 
 
This MOU contains the entire understanding of the Parties with regard to the  
provision of Services identified herein and supersedes all previous 
correspondence / agreements / understanding. Any amendment, modification, 
change or revision to this MOU as mutually agreed between the Parties hereto shall 
be made in writing. 
21. COUNTERPARTS 
 
This MOU may be executed in two (2) counterparts, each of which when  
executed and delivered shall constitute an original of this MOU but shall  
together constitute one and only the MOU.

Annexure - 1 
 
The Call4Svasth (C4S) program is a system innovation in primary healthcare 
- it focuses on achieving wellness among vulnerable populations. It aims to  
provide affordable quality primary healthcare activities for vulnerable 
populations and facilitate access to a range of existing secondary and tertiary 
care providers using a Physical Model. The model combines medical, 
behavioral, and social science with an appropriate mix of technology. 
 
The Program seeks to enhance the health and well -being of populations 
through these key  strategies; (i)  Immediate Primary  healthcare access,  (ii) 
Health agency among the populations by educating them on targeted health  
information and promotion, (iii)  Referral network creation and navigate 
population access to treatment nearby facilities (iv) Accessible Psycho -social 
/ Emotional Healthcare via targeted counselling (v) Facilitation of Social  
Protection schemes in place for the community by the government to 
establish social and financial security. 
 
Pragati Organization is responsible for implementing the C4S program among 
their community. They generate demand for C4S services through conducted 
surveys via C4S app or mass awareness campaigns. 
 
 
Reporting mechanism: 
As a part of this partnership, if required Swasti could request Pragati Organisation 
to share implementation impact through numbers and testimonials from the field.

2. Purpose of the Grant 
2.1. Tata AIG intends to support projects for promoting Social Protection among poor and 
vulnerable communities in the states of Uttar Pradesh, Nagaland and Maharashtra by 
facilitating healthcare and insurance Schemes provided by Central and State 
Governments through Social Protection Help desk. This Grant Amount shall be utilized for 
the sole purpose of funding the Project that is promoting Social Protection Services among 
poor and vulnerable communities by Swasti & Field implementation entities in Uttar 
Pradesh, Maharashtra & Nagaland States through awareness and uptake of select Central 
and/or State Govt. Health Insurance and rela ted Schemes (“Purpose”) and as per the 
budget allocation as more particularly set out Annexure 1. The Grant Amount shall not be 
used for any purpose other than the Purpose as specified in this Agreement, without prior 
written consent of Tata AIG. 
 
3. Project Interventions 
The key interventions envisaged as part of the Project shall include:  
● Ensuring community members and families are well -informed about pertinent health -
related insurance schemes and services offered by both Central and state governments. 
● Facilitating uptake of a minimum of two schemes per individual through Help Desks, based 
on the specific needs and eligibility criteria of targeted groups and communities. 
● Facilitating individuals who have enrolled in said schemes to receive their eligible claim 
and other benefits promptly and appropriately by seeking support of govt authorities and 
key stakeholders. 
● Establishing a functional mechanism to deliver community -friendly critical health-related 
services and schemes to members and their families. 
      
Project Outcome (Quantitative)

ANNEXURE 1 – CSR PROJECT DETAILS 
A. Background or Overview   
      
Ensuring social protection and equitable access to health care, including health insurance 
schemes, is of paramount importance for the vulnerable communities residing in urban areas. 
The complex dynamics of urban settings characterized by population density, migration, resource 
disparities, necessitate a c omprehensive approach to address the healthcare needs of the 
vulnerable groups. 
  
Urban vulnerable groups face barriers to accessing social protection programs, including 
healthcare, due to factors like limited awareness, bureaucratic complexity, d ocumentation 
demands, and geographical disparities. Many lack formal employment and struggle to afford 
health insurance. Medical expenses deter them from seeking care. Some are unaware of 
available support, while administrative hurdles discourage enrollmen t. Inequalities persist, with 
gender bias and infrastructure issues impacting access.  
      
Despite well-crafted health and welfare programs, reaching urban poor and vulnerable families is 
challenging. Weak enforcement and accountability worsen the situation. Government officials 
also face practical obstacles, hindering effective promotion of these programs and missing 
outreach opportunities. Urban-focused initiatives are needed as rural-oriented programs may not 
fit urban c hallenges. Partnerships between government and private sectors aim to expand 
coverage for urban vulnerable groups. 
      
B. Baseline or Needs-assessment   
      
The first step would be conducting a situational need assessment using Secondary research. This 
will involve analyzing the existing resources for a comprehensive examination of communities or 
families evaluating their specific requirements, challenges, and opportunities. The assessment 
will draw from secondary sources like ex isting research, data, reports, and expertise of local 
CBOs working in those geographies to gain insights into the current conditions. By utilizing these 
sources, a profound comprehension of the present status of the families/community members will 
be derived, enabling informed decision-making and strategic planning. 
      
Additionally, if deeper insight into the community is needed, a Baseline need assessment will be 
carried out to map the societal status of community groups. This baseline assessme nt will be 
conducted at the district levels before project activities commence. This process aids in 
comprehending the current needs of community members and establishes a baseline for 
measuring project impact. Structured questionnaires will be administere d for interviews with 
approximately 5 to 10% of the population, along with interviews with management. Furthermore, 
two focus group discussions involving around 10 to 12 community members will be conducted. 
      
C. CSR Project Objective(s)      
      
1. Enhance public awareness of healthcare services and insurance options via 
community-level events, group meetings, and peer communication.

2. Empower individuals and communities to make informed choices about health and 
insurance for better healthcare utilization. 
3. Improve access to healthcare and insurance in rural and marginalized areas. 
4. Provide financial protection to vulnerable populations against high medical costs. 
5. Address disparities in healthcare access among various socioeconomi c groups, 
including women, SC/ST community members, and people with disabilities. 
6. Cultivate partnerships with government agencies, civil society, and private sectors to 
enhance project implementation effectiveness.

F. Key Communities: Project Beneficiaries 
This project is aimed at serving Key Communities namely … 
      
● Urban Poor (Weaker sections-women, old age) 
● Street Vendors 
● Weavers 
● Widows/ destitute 
● Migrants 
● Persons with disability 
● Key population (PLHIV, Sex workers, Transgender) 
● Marginalized groups (SC, ST, OBC) 
      
Selection or eligibility criteria for project beneficiaries is as follows:…  
      
• The selection of the members who are in need for the SP services will be through 
Secondary research data extracted from district administration followed by line listing from 
State AIDS control society (SACS) on the key populations data f urther the implementing 
partners will be having the existing data which they have been working on in the 
intervention sites. Apart from these State departments data will be collected on the needs 
of the different categories of the communities. Further the criteria may include- 
• Priority given to recognized members of key communities - urban poor, street vendors, 
weavers, widows/destitute, migrants, disabled persons, key populations (PLHIV, sex 
workers, transgender), marginalized groups (SC, ST, OBC). 
• preference for the most vulnerable within communities - women, elderly, socially 
marginalized.  
• Emphasis on exceptionally vulnerable subgroups - single mothers, orphaned children, 
unsupported elderly, severe health cases.

G. Aligning to Tata Affirmative Action Program (TAAP) 
This project endorses and aligns itself to the belief of Tata Group and Tata AIG in social equity 
and inclusive growth. In adherence to Affirmative Action (AA) Policy, this project would 
contribute to Tata AIG’s commitment of working towards ensuring an equal footing to socially 
and economically disadvantaged sections of the society in the country at large and specifically 
the Scheduled Caste (SC) and Scheduled Tribe Communities. The expanded definition of AA 
Communities by Tata Group in 2020 additionally includes Persons with Disability (PwD) and 
Women.

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING 
This Memorandum of Understanding (hereinafter referred to as “ MOU”) is entered on this 
[15 June 2023] and is made effective from (“20 June 2023”) 
BY AND BETWEEN 
Swasti, registered under the Karnataka Societies Registration Act 1960, having its registered 
office at No. 25 Raghavendra Nilaya, AECS Layout, Ashwathnagar, Bangalore – 560094 
(hereinafter referred to as " Swasti”" which expression shall, unless repugnant to or 
inconsistent with the context or meaning thereof, be deemed to include its successors and 
permitted assigns)  
 
AND 
Sattva Media and Consulting Private Limited, a company  incorporated/registered under the 
Companies Act, 1956, having its registered off ice at # 294 / 295, 2nd Floor, Amar Jyothi 
Layout, Domlur, Bangalore - 560071, India (hereinafter referred as “ Partner”, which 
expression shall, unless repugnant to or inconsistent with the context or meaning thereof, be 
deemed to include its successors and permitted assigns)  
 
Swasti and Partner shall be collectively referred to as “Parties” and individually as “Party”. 
 
WHEREAS: 
A. Swasti is a global south civil society organisation that is committed to adding 100 
million healthy days for vulnerable communit ies. It brings the missing pieces of 
wellness together (mental, social, financial, environmental, systematic) to elevate the 
discourse from physical health to overall well -being. It integrates the 
technical/medical aspects with other aspects of wellbeing, with a strong focus on 
prevention and promotion.  
 
B. The Partner is contributing to health systems transformation through data, analytics, 
and digital platforms. 
 
C. Swasti and the Partner are desirous of collaborating to be a Technical Support Partner 
in the i mplementation of Community Led Monitoring Project funded byUSAID 
(“Collaboration”) and in furtherance of the same wish to enter this MOU to set out 
the terms and conditions of this Collaboration

IT HAS BEEN AGREED BETWEEN THE PARTIES AS FOLLOWS: 
1. EFFECTIVE DATE AND TERM. 
This MOU is deemed to have come into force as on the Effective Date (20 June 2023) 
and shall be valid for a period of 3 (Three) years, unless the Parties decide to mutually 
terminate this MOU in accordance with the terms outlined herein. 
2. KEY DELIVERABLES, ROLES, AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF EACH PARTY 
OF THE MOU. 
2.1. The key deliverables, roles, and responsibilities of each Party have been specifically 
outlined in Annexure A (Key Deliverables, Roles, and Responsibilities) to this MOU. 
2.2. Each Party shall in good faith and on a best efforts basis, fulfill their respective roles 
and responsibilities, dedicate adequate personnel and resources, and ensure the 
success of the aforementioned Collaboration.  
3. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY. 
3.1. For the purpose of this MOU, “ Intellectual Property ” or “ Intellectual Property 
Rights” shall mean any and all trademarks and services marks (whether or not 
registered), copyrights, design rights (whether or not registered), moral rights, patents, 
performance rights, database rights, WA P and other new media rights, names, logos 
and codes, publicity rights, and any and all other intellectual property and proprietary 
rights of any nature whatsoever that subsist, or may subsist, or be capable of 
registration, in any jurisdiction anywhere in the world. 
3.2. All pre-existing intellectual property rights shall continue to vest with the owner of 
such intellectual property rights. 
 
3.3. All Intellectual Property Rights jointly made, developed, conceived, first reduced to 
practice, fixed in any tangible med ium of expression or created by either Parties 
pursuant to this MOU (“ Joint Intellectual Property ”), shall be the joint property of 
both the Parties and each Party shall enjoy all rights and privileges accorded for 
ownership and usage of such Joint Intelle ctual Property without accounting to the 
other. The manner/terms and conditions with respect to the usage of Joint Intellectual 
Property shall be mutually decided and agreed by and between the Parties. 
 
3.4. Further, the Parties hereby grants to each other a no n-exclusive, non-transferable right 
to copy, use and display the other Party’s logo, wordmark, trademark and such other 
Intellectual Property Rights on any and all mediums in which such Party publishes 
any content prepared by the Parties in relation to thi s MOU and Collaboration, 
provided that usage of such Intellectual Property is in an agreed form, and is prior 
approved by the other Party. 
3.5. Neither Party shall acquire any ownership rights in or to the other Party’s Intellectual 
Property Rights by virtue o f it using and displaying the latter’s Intellectual Property 
on any medium (as may be agreed by and between the Parties).

The Parties shall work on a principle to principle basis and as independent contractors.

15. GOVERNING LAW AND JURISDICTION 
This MOU shall be construed and enforced in accordance with the laws of India 
without regard to its principles of conflict of laws provisions. Subject to Clause 16 
below, the Courts in Bangalore shall have the exclusive jurisdiction to entertain any 
disputes arising out of, under, or in relation to, the provisions of this MOU, including

16. DISPUTE RESOLUTION 
16.1. Any and all disputes arising out of or in connection with this MOU shall be referred 
by written notice, and the Parties shall meet and endeavour to resolve the disp ute 
within [90] days. Parties can by mutual agreement extend the period of resolution in 
the above process.   
 
16.2. In the event the Parties are unable to resolve the dispute in accordance with Clause 
16.1 above, the Parties shall submit such dispute to mediati on at the Centre for

Advance Mediation Practice (“CAMP”), Bangalore under the CAMP Rules of

16.3. If the dispute between the Parties is not resolved through mediation, the same shall be 
resolved by arbitration in accordance with the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996. 
The Dispute shall be settled by a sole arbitrator to be appointed by the Parties to the 
dispute. If the Parties are unable to appoint a sole arbitrator by way of mutual consent, 
then such arbitrator shall be appointed pursuant to the provisions of Section 11 of the 
Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996. The seat of arbitration shall be Bangalore, 
India and the arbitration proceedings shall be governed by the provisions of the 
Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, as amended from time to time. All arbitration 
proceedings shall be conducted in English. The arbitration award shall be final and 
binding on the Parties and shall be enforceable in any competent court of law, and the 
Parties agree to be bound thereby and to act accordingly. 
 
16.4. Notwithstanding anything stated to the contrary in this MOU, neither of the Parties 
shall be precluded from seeking interim or permanent equitable or injunctive relief, or 
both, from any court having jurisdiction to grant the same. The pursuit of equitable  or 
injunctive relief shall not be a waiver of the duty of the Parties to pursue any remedy 
for monetary damages through the mediation and/or arbitration as specified above.

natural person (“Personal Data”) on behalf of the other Party in complying with 
its obligations under this MOU,  the Parties agrees to comply with all applicable 
laws, regulations, and orders relating to data protecti on, privacy, data security, or 
the Processing of Personal Data in India (“ Data Protection Laws ”). As used in 
this Section, the terms “Controller”, “Processor”, “Processing” (and related terms 
such as "Process", “Processes” and “Processed”) shall have the meanings given to 
those terms (or equivalent terms) under Data Protection Laws. 
22.2. ROLE OF THE PARTIES. Personal Data shall be considered as Confidential 
Information and afforded all of the protections set forth in Clause 5. In addition to 
and without limiting the terms generally applicable to Confidential Information, 
the parties agree that each shall process, apply, view, and use Personal Data only 
to the extent necessary to perform  their obligations under this Agreement. Neither 
party shall transfer or otherwise allow the use of Personal Data of the other party 
unless expressly instructed or authorized by the other party. Both parties shall 
comply with applicable laws and best pract ices relating to data privacy and data 
security. 
22.3. DATA PROCESSING OBLIGATIONS: With respect to Personal Data, Each Party will: 
Page 8 of 12
 
22.3.1. Only Process Personal Data to fulfill its obligations under this MOU and in 
accordance with the other Party’s instructions. Each P arty will inform the 
other Party if they become aware of an instruction that the other Party (in its 
reasonable opinion) considers it to be abreach of Data Protection Laws;  
22.3.2. Each Party shall treat Personal Data as Confidential Information and 
implement appropriate technical measures to safeguard Personal Data from 
data breaches or other misuse, and limit access to Personal Data to third 
parties or other personnel who in respec t of such data have executed written 
confidentiality agreements that survive termination of the personnel 
engagement; 
22.3.3. Each Party shall inform in writing without undue delay (and in any event 
within 24 hours) of becoming aware of any breach of security lead ing to the 
accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorized disclosure 
of, or access to, Personal Data (“ Personal Data Breach ”) and provide the 
other Party with details of the Personal Data Breach. Each Party shall use 
best efforts to mit igate and remediate the Personal Data Breach and prevent 
similar Personal Data Breaches from occurring in the future; 
22.3.4. Not engage a third party (“Sub-Processor”) to Process Personal Data without 
the other Party’s written consent and, where such consent is obtained, enter 
into a written agreement with the Sub -Processor which imposes equivalent 
contractual terms on the Sub -Processor as imposed on Each Party under this 
MOU. Each Party will be responsible and liable for all acts, omissions, or 
defaults of its Sub -Processors in the performance of obligations under this 
MOU; 
22.3.5. Provide such cooperation and assistance as Each Party m ay reasonably 
request in complying with its obligations under Data Protection Laws, 
including, without limitation, with regards to responding to data subject 
requests, ensuring the security of Personal Data, notifying Personal Data 
Breaches, carrying out d ata protection impact assessments and any prior 
consultation with a data protection authority where required by Data 
Protection Laws; and 
22.3.6. On termination of the Agreement for whatever reason, or upon written 
request from either Party at any time, cease to u se or Process any Personal 
Data, (if requested either Party) return a copy of the Personal Data to the 
requesting Party, and securely delete or destroy, as applicable, all Personal 
Data in the other Party’s possession or control, unless applicable law requires 
either Party to continue to Process Personal Data (in which case, either Party 
will inform the other Party of such applicable law and continue to keep 
Personal Data confidential). 
 
 
Page 9 of 12
 
22.4. TRANSFERS. Each Party represents and warrants that all cross -border transfers of 
Personal Data initiated by either Party or its Sub -Processors shall comply with 
data transfer requirements under Data Protection Laws. 
 
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Parties hereto have duly executed this MOU as of the date 
and year hereinabove first written

Memorandum of Understanding 
This Memorandum of Understanding (“MoU” or “Agreement”) is made on 1st December_,2023 between 
Community Action Collab (Hereinafter referred to as “CAC”) represented through Catalyst Foundation, 
a Trust registered under The Indian Trust Act, 1882 having its registered address at  No 36, Vinayaka 
layout, Bhoopasandra Main road Bangalore 560094, AND 
Lipok Social Foundation,  (Hereinafter referred to as the “Member Organization”), a non-Profit Company 
registered under Section 8 of the Companies Act, 2013, having its registered office at RH 10, Sector 2, 
Hindustan Awas, Nakshatrawadi, Aurangabad 431001. 
CAC and Member Organization shall be jointly referred to as the “Parties”. 
WHEREAS: 
A. CAC is a platform of multidisciplinary members, including the Member Organization, that 
collaborate with each other to enable the resilience of vulnerable people (Hereinafter referred 
to as “VP”) by building their individual and collective agency to overcome disasters that impact 
their lives and livelihoods. 
B. CAC seeks to enhance: (i) resilience for 10 million vulnerable people in their lives and livelihoods; 
(b) resilience for 100 organisations focussed on vulnerable people (VPs) for future humanitarian 
emergencies; (c) and create a ‘spring to action’ ready re sourced platform that is available to 
respond to emergencies present in key vulnerable districts. 
C. The Member Organization is a Non-profit Company registered under Section 8 of the Companies 
Act, 2013 working on sustainable livelihoods, resilient agriculture, climate c hange adaptation, 
water conservation and management, and rural enterprises , mainly in Aurangabad district of 
Maharashtra. 
D. Resilience at the household level is the ability of the marginalised and vulnerable to absorb, 
bounce back from or adapt to any disruption without compromising their long -term wellbeing. 
However, the household does not exist in isolation. It is inter-connected with the community and 
the ecosystem. Therefore Resilience is the capability and characteristics of the inter-connected 
system of household-community-ecosystem to regenerate, prosper and improve when exposed 
to shocks and disturbances in an unpredictable and volatile environment. 
E. The Parties will play a key role in designing and delivering the integrated services pertaining to 
building resilience of the aforementioned VPs across the 4 (four) domains of health, livelihood, 
social protection and climate action-DRR. They will be expanding the services and programmes 
for their existing VP communities with support from member organisations of the collaborative 
and other sectoral entities and partners. 
CAC aims to collaborate with other organisations that share its vision (hereafter referred to as 
“Members/Member Organisations/Party”). It provides a collaborative mechanism for its members with 
the interconnectedness of household-community-ecosystem that will rally support to these VP-focussed 
organisations for an integrated resilience building plan for the households. The mechanism is facilitated 
by a team (hereafter referred to as the “CAC Secretariat/Party”). 

Page | 2 
The CAC Secretariat has drawn this MOU to ensure mutual clarity on the expectations with regard to the 
collaborative engagement. 
TERMSOFTHEAGREEMENT 
1. Commitments by the Member Organisations and CAC Secretariat on collaborative 
working 
Shared goal: 
The Member Organisation commits to building resilience of the VPs they work with and their 
institution. Building resilience of VPs should be a part of the organisation's strategic plans with 
endorsement from their leadership team and governing body. 
The CAC Secretariat will ensure orientation and perspective building of the member organisation for 
the resilience journey with their VPs. 
Time and Investments: 
The Member Organisation commits resources to work as part of CAC, on building individual and 
collective agency of VP to enable resilience building. . The Member Organisation will strive to invest 
at least 4 (four) days per month until the plans are prepared and further resourced (which may take 
at least 6 (six) months). 
The resilience plans for each Member Organisation comprises requests for support from other nodes 
and CAC members, as well as resource and implementation strategies. 
The CAC secretariat will provide enabling support and advisory inputs to the Member Organisations 
pertaining to resource mobilisation, communications, technology etc., as well as facilitation of 
collaborations, wherever feasible, to strengthen the capacity of the Member Organization to meet 
shared goals and build the resilience of target communities. 
Collaboration through Nodes: 
A core element of the CAC strategy is the coming together of Member Organisations that work with 
identified VPs, or in identified domains, or in specific geographies (hereafter referred to as “VP Node, 
Domain Node, Geography Node”). 
The members in these nodes collaborate and identify issues for that community, domain or 
geography that are barriers to resilience. The Member Organisation will participate in the CAC nodes 
of which they are members, for representation of community voices and co-creation of initiatives. 
They will collaborate with other nodes, as and when required. 
The CAC Secretariat will facilitate formation of VP , geography and domain nodes and support their 
governance and operation. The Secretariat will support intra and inter-nodal collaboration (match-
making of asks/gives between nodes). 

Page | 3 
Design and Delivery of Resilience Packages: 
The Parties will co-create, adapt and/or design strategies for integrated services across the domains 
of health, livelihood, social protection and climate action-DRR for selected VP segments as mutually 
identified by them (hereafter referred to as the “Resilience Package”) 
The Member Organization will implement the resilience package and/or any other packages 
developed during the course of the engagement and facilitate access to their communities for 
resilience building initiatives by other Member Organisations of the collab orative, as mutually 
agreed. 
The CAC Secretariat will connect the Member Organisation for technical support including, but not 
limited to capacity-building of Member Organisations for delivery of resilience building packages. 
Leverage the CAC Platform: 
The CAC platform will employ technology to facilitate collaborative working and achievement of 
mutually defined objectives 
Communications: 
The Member Organisation will provide information and any other inputs for communications, policy 
and research insights, monitoring, evaluation and learning and ensure usage of CAC’s platforms and 
systems (with due consideration of Intellectual Properties and Copyrights). 
Data: 
The CAC Secretariat will maintain systems that allow for sharing and capturing data (information 
related to the Resilience Journey), analysis and sharing insights in ways that enable all stakeholders 
to make better decisions, and anticipate and solve problems effectively. 
The data shall be collected for the purpose of evaluating the experiences and competencies of 
households with respect to the Resilience Journey. This information shall include specific data points 
on the household level such as individuals' names, gender, age, income, occupation, and household 
sizes within the respective communities. Furthermore, the data shall be utilized to scrutinize the 
absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of individuals within the community concerning 
factors such as health, infrastructure, and livelihood etc. Additionally, the data shall exclusively serve 
the objectives of research, analysis, reporting, monitoring, evaluation and similar activities, without 
being employed for any purposes that extend beyond the stipulated scope of this Memorandum of 
Understanding (MoU). 
The Parties acknowledge and agree that the said data shall be collected, stored and managed as per 
the applicable laws of India, with the informed consent of beneficiaries being duly taken with respect 
to the purpose and manner of usage of the said data. 
Further, the said data shall be jointly owned by both Parties, with either Party taking prior approval 
from the other for its dissemination in any format on a public forum, including appropriate 
attribution of credit to the other Party. 

Page | 4 
Collaboratively Raise Resources: 
The Member Organisation and the CAC Secretariat will explore joint fundraising opportunities, and 
showcase proposed initiatives/projects to donors, resource providers or other third -party 
stakeholders as mutually agreed upon by the members. 
The CAC Secretariat encourages Member Organisations to collaborate freely with each other for 
mutually defined objectives, including resource mobilisation. 
Member Organisations are requested to intimate the CAC Secretariat regarding such collaborations. 
The abovementioned engagements should be brought to the notice of the Secretariat for record. 
2. Financial Transactions: 
The collaboration may involve financial transactions between the two parties, and such transactions 
are not within the scope of this MOU. The parties may therefore jointly decide to enter into separate, 
legally binding agreements related to financial commi tments, funding, taxes, or cost -sharing for 
specific aspects of the collaboration. The same will be drafted taking into account the governing 
relevant statutory laws and regulations. Such agreements will supersede and replace any non -
binding provisions related to financial matters outlined in this MOU. 
3. Intellectual Property, Confidentiality and Communications: 
Creation of content and material: 
As a result of the collaborative nature of engagement, CAC and the Member Organizations may 
jointly create content/frameworks/models/intervention designs/other related documents etc. Such 
material will be jointly owned for use, distribution, communication by each Party as they see fit, 
giving due acknowledgement to the other. 
All pre-existing intellectual property rights shall continue to vest with the owner of such 
intellectual property rights. 
Use of logos and publications: 
The collaborative relationship may involve amplification of each other's work which may involve the 
creation and/or use of communications content such as brochures, proposals, posts on social media 
etc. 
Both Parties will abide by each others’ brand and communication guidelines and will seek mutual 
permissions to use each others’ names, logos, trademarks, other proprietary marks and branding 
material or before it is shared publicly. 
Both Parties agree to seek approvals from the other prior to the publication of any materials in digital 
or print media, including promotional materials, annual reports, social media handles (including but 
not limited to Meta, Facebook, X, LinkedIn etc.). 
This clause does not create any legal rights or obligations with regard to the use of logos or 
trademarks. It is intended to promote goodwill and visibility between the Parties but is not intended 
to create a legally binding licensing agreement. 
4. Confidentiality: 
Each Party may be given access to Confidential Information from the other Party in order to perform its 
obligations under this MoU. The Party that receives Confidential Information shall be known as 

Page | 5 
“Receiving Party”. The Party that discloses Confidential Information shall be known as “ Disclosing 
Party”. The Receiving Party shall use the Confidential Information of the Disclosing Party only for 
purposes of this MoU and shall not, directly or indirectly, deal with, use or exploit, or disclose such 
Confidential Information or any part thereof to any person or entity, for any purpose whatsoever, except 
as expressly permitted hereunder or unless and until expressly authorized in writing to do so by the 
Disclosing Party. 
For the purposes of this MoU, “Confidential Information” means any and all data or information that 
is of value to a Party, and is not generally known in the industry or to competitors of a Party, and 
includes, but is not limited to, business information, business plans, financial statements, specifications, 
research, trade secrets, discoveries, ideas, know -how, designs, drawings, flow charts, data, reports, 
programs, marketing plans, budget figures, and other technical, financial and business information 
concerning a Party, or any such information of clients, customers, partners, parents, affiliates, 
subsidiaries or agents of a Party, which is disclosed by such Party (the “ Disclosing Party”), whether 
directly in oral or material form to the other Party (the “Receiving Party”), or indirectly, by permitting 
the Receiving Party to observe the conduct of the Disclosing Party’s various operations or processes. 
The Receiving Party acknowledges that the Confidential Information is received on a confidential basis, 
and that the Disclosing Party shall remain the exclusive owner of its Confidential Information and of all 
patents, copyrights, trade secrets, trademarks and other Intellectual Property Rights therein. 
Confidentiality obligations specified above will not apply to the following cases: 
a. Such Confidential Information has been placed in the public domain other than through the fault 
of the Receiving Party; 
b. The Confidential Information has already been in the possession of the Receiving Party before the 
Disclosing party provided it to the Receiving Party; 
c. The Confidential Information has been received by the Receiving Party from a third party; 
d. The Confidential Information was developed independently by the Receiving Party without any 
inputs from the Disclosing Party; 
e. The Receiving Party is required to disclose the Confidential Information by law. 
5. Compliances: 
○ By signing this MoU, the Parties explicitly acknowledge and confirm that they have necessary 
licences, certification/registration and permits from the relevant statutory authorities and abide 
by statutory compliances required under the applicable law . 
○ The Parties further represent and warrant that they shall continue to comply with all applicable 
laws and regulations required to carry out their operations through the duration of this MoU and 
any other engagements that they may undertake with CAC Secretariat, whether by way of separate 
agreements or otherwise. 
○ The Parties acknowledge and agree to share an immediate communication in writing, in the event 
of any change in the status of registrations, licences, etc. Any failure to maintain the said licences, 
registration, etc may significantly impact the nature of the collaboration and the CAC may choose 
to terminate this MOU immediately without prior notice to the Member Organization. 

Page | 6 
6. No Pending Litigation: 
The Parties warrant that to the best of their knowledge and belief, they are not currently a party to 
any legal dispute, pending litigation or arbitration proceedings that may significantly impact their 
ability to undertake its objectives under this MOU. In the event that either Party is impleaded or has 
reasonable grounds to assume that their parent or affiliate entities, subsidiaries are involved in any 
litigation, dispute or arbitration that affects their engagement under this MOU, the same must be 
communicated immediately in writing. Either Party may choose to terminate this MOU if the other 
Party’s ability to perform its objectives is significantly impacted by the said litigation / ongoing 
disputes. 
7. Amendment: 
This MOU may be amended or modified only by mutual consent of the parties in the form of a written 
agreement and signed by its authorised representatives, which would form an annexure to this MOU. 
8. Termination: 
This MOU shall remain in force for a period of 3 (three) years from the Effective Date, unless 
terminated earlier by mutual agreement between both Parties or by either Party subject to clauses 
mentioned above. Either Party may choose to terminate this MOU by providing advance written 
notice of 30 (thirty) days to the other Party. 
Effects of Termination: 
○ In the event of termination, the Parties in good faith must complete their ongoing projects and 
activity to the best of their abilities over the course of the notice period stipulated under this 
clause. 
○ Both Parties shall return or dispose of any confidential information, proprietary materials, or other 
items exchanged during the course of the collaboration in a manner that respects the 
confidentiality and intellectual property rights of the disclosing party. The handover of any material 
jointly created specifically for the purpose of this MOU i.e. building resilience of VPs. and 
organisations under the CAC Platform will be mutually dealt with between the Parties on a case to 
case basis. 
9. Non-Binding Effect and Non-Exclusivity: 
a) This MoU is not intended to create a formal contractual relationship or legally enforceable rights 
and obligations between the Parties, including but not limited to any financial or material 
obligations, rights or duties. It is only intended to express the  Parties' mutual interest in 
collaborating with each other to meet objectives jointly defined by them. 
b) This MOU does not constitute a commitment, an offer or an undertaking of any kind by the 
Parties to proceed with any transaction or to enter into an agreement in connection with any 
transaction. Neither Party shall have any obligation with respect to any t ransaction and/or 
contract by virtue of this MOU, nor shall either Party have the right to compel the other party to 
enter a transaction or a contract therewith, unless and until a separate Agreement (Hereinafter 
referred to as the “Definitive Agreement”) has been executed between them. 
c) Nothing in this MOU shall likewise be construed as a limitation, prohibition, or restraint for either 
Parties to contract with other entities or potential partners for the same or similar purpose. 

Page | 7 
However, it is the responsibility of such Party to maintain the confidentiality under this 
Agreement or the Definitive Agreement. 
10. Limitation of Liability 
In no event shall the CAC Secretariat incur liability for any collaborations or engagements undertaken 
by Member Organisations with each other, whether facilitated by CAC or by and between the Member 
Organisations in their own capacity. The interaction bet ween each Member Organization shall be 
treated in the capacity of individual entities on a principal-to-principal basis, and neither Party nor the 
CAC Secretariat shall be treated as an agent of the other. Further, the CAC Secretariat shall not be 
responsible for, nor bear any legal responsibility for any actions or results arising out of these 
engagements between Member Organisations. 
11. Notice: 
Each notice, demand or other communication given or made under this MoU shall be in writing 
and delivered or sent to the relevant Party at the postal address or email address set out below 
(or such other postal address or email address as the addressee has  by 5 (five) business Days' 
prior written notice specified). 
The initial address, email and telephone numbers for the Parties for the purposes are:
